newsitem.title: UK: Scientists ask why Guinness bubbles go down.
newsitem.headline: Scientists ask why Guinness bubbles go down.

text.p: British scientists are trying to solve the great drinks riddle -- Why do bubbles in Guinness stout go down and not up?
Ireland's national drink is being put under the microscope by researchers at York University in northern England who are using laser technology to study the descending bubbles.
"The answers will be relevant to the storage of beers and perhaps the brewing process," Professor Klaus Muller-Dethlefs said after a Zero Energy Kinetic Spectroscopy workshop.
Guinness drinkers have, above all, to be patient. The thick black beer with its distinctive creamy white top is best poured slowly and allowed to settle before they can enjoy it.
